WINDOWS

exterior
interior

Windows come in a variety of construction methods and materials. It is important to understand how to properly maintain the window after proper installation from each manufacturer.
Each year inspect the caulking around exterior window frames and (using a quality silicone door & window sealant) touch up any areas that have pulled loose or sunken due to weathering.

Always be sure to scrape away loose caulking and clean the surfaces where it will be replaced.

If you have wooden windows, or wooden exterior trim, these should also be inspected for flaking, cracked or damaged paint. A quality exterior paint should be used to repair deficient areas.
As illustrated in the picture to the left, rot can happen quickly even on newer homes that are not properly maintained. Be sure to include all wood trim at cornerboard, attic vents, door pediments, etc. while inspecting your window and door trim.
See also: Doors
Many times wooden windows are not painted per the manufacturer's recommendations. Periodically check
that the bottom of the frames, and areas where floating sashes meet, have been primed and paint is not worn thin in these areas.
Like any surface exposed to outside elements, your windows or doors will get dirty and require periodic cleaning.Often, heavy rains will will accomplish this for you, however you can restore the splendor of the windows or doors simply by washing with a mild detergent (if necessary) and a soft cloth or soft bristle brush. Do not wash the windows or doors with a high pressure spray since extreme pressure could crack or destroy the caulking around the window or door that provides leak protection.
If you have aluminum or vinyl tilt to clean windows, be sure that the window is raised a few inches in most cases to prevent damage to the frame.
If you know the manufacturer of your window and door units, write them to obtain information for their care and maintenance that is specific to your brand. This will help assure proper compliance for the warranty period.
